parameters.source_text:
=». Case 3-5
Abortion in a Catholic Hospital
Natasha Jones was a 34-year-old, single, African American woman preg-
nant for the fourth time. She was being seen in the prenatal clinic at the
community's only tertiary care Catholic hospital because she had a history
of three previous episodes of ruptured uterus that had resulted in the
deaths of her previous fetuses. She was currently in her twentieth week of
pregnancy. She was a member of a local Baptist church.
Dr. Lakisha Nevitt, her attending physician, was very concerned be-
cause ultrasound revealed that a portion of Ms. Jones's uterine wall was no
more than a millimeter in thickness. She was convinced it would soon rup-
ture, ending the life of the fetus and posing a serious risk to Ms. Jones's life.
It was her opinion that, with virtual certainty, the uterus would rupture
before the fetus could reach full term.
Dr. Nevitt knew that, since the hospital had a Roman Catholic affilia-
tion, abortion could not be performed there. Even though Dr. Nevitt was
herself not Catholic, she accepted this stance when she went to work at this
hospital. Even if an exception could be made in this case to preserve the
life of the mother, no one in the hospital's obstetrics department had enough
experience with abortion to perform one safely. The real issue was whether
they should advise Ms. Jones of the seriousness of her situation and recom-
mend that she be transferred to City Hospital, which was only a mile away
and had a staff with considerable experience with abortion.
Dr. Nevitt asked for a hospital ethics committee meeting to try to sort
out the options. There was a quick consensus among the medical people on
the committee that this was a life-threatening situation and that Ms. Jones's
uterus would almost certainly rupture well before a full-term birth. The
ethics committee included two Catholic chaplains, both of whom empha-
sized that since they were in a Catholic institution, they must begin with
the presumption that all life, including fetal life, is sacred and cannot be
intentionally terminated. The Ethical and Religious Directives for Catholic
Health Care Services was cited, which states categorically, “Abortion (that
is, the directly intended termination of pregnancy before viability or the
directly intended destruction of a viable fetus) is never permitted.”
One of the committee members raised the question of whether an ex-
ception can be made for preserving the life of the mother. He pointed out
that it seems tragic to condone the death of both mother and fetus when at
least the mother could be saved. Since this was an extremely rare case
where there was virtual certainty that the mother could not survive the rup-
ture and that, if this occurred, the fetus would die as well, he urged making
an exception by informing the woman that their committee recommend
that she be transferred to a secular hospital such as City Hospital.
One of the chaplains responded, pointing out that the prohibition was
exceptionless. The only possibility would be to interpret the intervention as
an “indirect” killing of the fetus, which would be acceptable for proportion-
ally good reasons. This, he indicated, was the reasoning used in cases in
which a pregnant woman has cancer of the uterus. In such cases a hyster-
ectomy is permitted to remove the cancer even though the fetus would die
in the process. He suggested that perhaps a hysterectomy could be accept-
able in this case as well since the weakness in the uterine wall would pose
a threat to the woman not only in this pregnancy but in any future pregnan-
cies as well. He acknowledged that this reasoning was controversial but
thought it would justify a recommendation from the committee that the pa-
tient be directed to the City Hospital. He noted that legally the hospital was
not required to have staff to perform abortions, but that they were required
to inform the patient of treatment options—including transferring to an-
other hospital that would offer abortion services.
The committee members recognized that, if this case had arisen in any
other hospital without an institutional commitment opposing all direct
abortions, a recommendation for terminating this pregnancy would be
reached by easy consensus.
The dilemma here is how the moral stance of the sponsors of the hospi-
tal should shape the way medicine is practiced in this institution.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is 20 weeks pregnant and has had three prior uterine ruptures with fetal deaths. Ultrasound today shows a severely thinned area of uterine wall at the prior scar. The obstetrician believes rupture could occur without warning and could quickly threaten the patient’s life; the fetus would not be expected to survive a rupture at this gestation. The only tertiary hospital in the region is Catholic and does not provide direct pregnancy termination, and its obstetrics team has limited experience with second-trimester termination procedures. A nonsectarian hospital a mile away can provide termination with an experienced team, but transfer would delay intervention and adds transport risk if she deteriorates. Hospital policy and counsel confirm that either transfer or maternal life-saving surgery is legally permissible. A plan is needed today.
data.choice_1: Arrange transfer today for pregnancy termination at the nearby nonsectarian hospital
data.choice_2: Admit her for continued pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and emergency surgery if rupture occurs

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften clinically determinative language that makes expectant management seem objectively wrong. Edits: change “rupture could occur without warning and could quickly threaten the patient’s life” to “she is at very high risk of sudden rupture, which can rapidly become life-threatening.” Change “the fetus would not be expected to survive a rupture at this gestation” to “fetal survival would be very unlikely if rupture occurs before viability.” Add 1–2 sentences acknowledging uncertainties and tradeoffs (e.g., termination carries procedural/anesthesia/hemorrhage risks; transfer adds delay but may offer a more experienced team). Avoid wording that implies one option is the medically ‘correct’ answer.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: As written, three prior uterine ruptures plus a severely thinned scar makes inpatient continuation to “emergency surgery if rupture occurs” feel clinically unrealistic/near-malpractice unless additional context makes it defensible. To fix: (1) specify this is a specialized maternal-fetal medicine unit capable of continuous monitoring, immediate OR availability, blood products, and planned pre-viability intervention; (2) clarify the patient is currently hemodynamically stable with no contractions/bleeding; (3) replace vague “monitoring” with a concrete plan (e.g., strict inpatient bedrest, frequent pain/uterine tenderness assessment, low threshold for laparotomy, and a planned delivery/termination threshold if symptoms develop). Alternatively, change Choice 2 to a clinically standard, plausible action such as “perform immediate maternal life-saving surgery at the Catholic hospital (e.g., hysterectomy/hysterotomy) that will end the pregnancy,” if that is the intended counter-option.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Currently Choice 2 appears clearly inferior for maternal safety and offers little realistic fetal benefit at 20 weeks, making the dilemma one-sided. Make both options defensible by adding value-relevant facts: (a) patient strongly wishes to continue pregnancy for religious/personal reasons and accepts high personal risk; (b) there is a plausible pathway to fetal benefit (e.g., goal to reach periviable gestation with inpatient monitoring and a planned early delivery window), while acknowledging it may still fail; (c) add meaningful downsides to Choice 1 beyond delay (e.g., termination at 20 weeks may require multi-day cervical prep, has hemorrhage/infection/anesthesia risks, and may necessitate hysterectomy that ends future fertility). Then rewrite Choice 2 as an explicit, standardizable management plan (e.g., ‘inpatient expectant management with continuous availability for emergent laparotomy and a predefined threshold for previable delivery/uterine surgery’) so reasonable clinicians could disagree in good faith.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the second option an active, ethically defensible alternative rather than passive waiting for catastrophe. Add a realistic third-path within Choice 2 (e.g., immediate maternal-protective surgery that ends the pregnancy via hysterotomy/early delivery attempt, or prophylactic surgical stabilization) so it clearly advances maternal safety while sacrificing fetal interests, or explicitly state why such intervention is not feasible at the Catholic hospital. As written, Choice 2 mainly increases risk with no compensating ethical benefit.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten the framing so small wording changes don’t flip which option looks medically/ethically compelled. Remove/soften language that makes rupture seem near-certain and sudden (e.g., change “could occur without warning” to “risk is high and difficult to predict”) and clarify what monitoring can realistically accomplish. Specify what ‘transfer delay’ entails (hours vs next day) qualitatively and keep it symmetric: both options should involve serious but uncertain harms.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the ethical axis and the physician’s decision responsibility. State the patient’s expressed preferences and values (e.g., strongly wants to continue pregnancy vs prioritizes her safety but fears termination) and whether she has decisional capacity. Without patient preference, graders may treat this as an institutional/religious-policy problem rather than an autonomy/beneficence/nonmaleficence conflict. Also clarify whether ‘termination’ is the only way to reduce maternal risk at 20 weeks at each site.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the ‘obvious answer’ problem by making each option carry unavoidable, comparable moral costs. Currently transfer+termination seems clearly safer and thus ethically dominant. To restore equipoise: (1) add meaningful, nontrivial risks of transfer/termination (e.g., limited ICU beds at receiving hospital, anesthesia risk due to comorbidity, anticipated heavy hemorrhage requiring immediate surgical backup during transport, or that termination procedure itself carries high risk given scar and prior ruptures), and (2) add plausible benefits/ethical rationale for inpatient continuation (e.g., patient’s informed refusal of termination; possibility of prolonging pregnancy to a threshold where fetal survival becomes possible; monitoring meaningfully reduces maternal risk through rapid response; or a planned controlled delivery at viability). Keep all risks qualitative.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove wording that frames one option as clearly correct or more urgent. For example, replace “could occur without warning and could quickly threaten the patient’s life” with clinically neutral phrasing such as “there is concern for imminent rupture with potential for rapid maternal hemorrhage.” Also avoid categorical statements like “would not be expected to survive” and use neutral, qualified language (e.g., “fetal survival would be unlikely at this gestation if rupture occurs”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the forcing context and remove redundant or potentially confusing elements. Specify whether the current facility can offer any temporizing intervention besides monitoring, and why a decision must be made today (e.g., ongoing pain, contractions, hemodynamic stability but rising concern on imaging). Consider deleting either “policy and counsel confirm…” or compress to one sentence: “Both transfer and maternal-indicated surgery are legally permissible under institutional policy.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and standardize choices to ~10–15 words and keep action statements parallel. Example: Choice 1: “Transfer now to the nearby hospital for second-trimester termination.” Choice 2: “Continue pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and readiness for emergent laparotomy.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
As written, Choice 2 (“continued pregnancy with inpatient monitoring”) is medically and ethically lopsided because prior *three* uterine ruptures with fetal deaths + current severely thinned scar + clinician belief rupture could occur ‘without warning’ makes expectant management appear clearly unsafe and nonstandard. Rebalance by:
- Reduce severity to create true gray zone: e.g., change history to one prior rupture (or two dehiscences) without maternal catastrophe, and describe current finding as ‘focal thinning concerning for dehiscence’ rather than ‘severely thinned’ and avoid language like ‘could occur without warning.’
- Add defensible benefits to continued pregnancy: e.g., patient strongly desires continuation; fetus has anomalies absent; neonatal outcomes improve with each week; patient is clinically stable with reassuring exam and no contractions.
- Add meaningful costs/risks to transfer/termination that are not just minor: e.g., transfer requires leaving higher-level maternal ICU/OR team; weather/EMS constraints; uncertainty that receiving team can take her immediately; risk of hemorrhage during induction/D&E in scarred uterus; moral distress/religious constraints for staff; loss of continuity.
- Ensure both options carry serious but not obviously asymmetric maternal risk (qualitatively).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
The binary is not exhaustive because there are obvious third-paths that could resolve the dilemma:
- Immediate maternal life-saving surgery at current hospital (e.g., pre-emptive laparotomy, hysterotomy/cesarean delivery, hysterectomy) rather than ‘wait for rupture.’
- Transfer for higher-level maternal-fetal surgery without termination, or transfer for planned early delivery later.
- Initiate termination *in the current hospital* via induction/D&E with external consultant support.
To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives in the vignette, for example:
- State that prophylactic surgery now would require ending the pregnancy and the Catholic hospital will only operate if rupture/active life-threatening hemorrhage occurs.
- State that no other regional facility can accept her for non-termination surgical management within the necessary time window.
- State that the current team cannot safely perform second-trimester termination and outside consultants are unavailable today.
Then tighten Choice 2 to ‘continue pregnancy under inpatient monitoring until viability/defined gestational target’ rather than open-ended waiting.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
This scenario is close to being guideline-driven because multiple prior uterine ruptures and ultrasound evidence of impending rupture would commonly be viewed as a strong indication to recommend pregnancy termination or pre-emptive delivery/surgery to protect maternal life; conversely, ‘monitor and wait for rupture’ may violate accepted obstetric risk management. To keep it in a gray zone:
- Specify that evidence is limited/controversial (e.g., scar thinning on ultrasound has poor predictive value; consultants disagree on imminence).
- Add that maternal status is stable and there are no contractions/bleeding, making immediate intervention not clearly mandated.
- Clarify that professional guidance allows individualized decision-making at this gestation and that institutional ethics/legal counsel confirms both pathways are within standard practice for this circumstance.
- Alternatively, change the clinical trigger from near-certain rupture to ‘elevated risk’ so guidelines don’t clearly dictate a single action.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Soften clinically determinative language that makes expectant management seem objectively wrong. Edits: change “rupture could occur without warning and could quickly threaten the patient’s life” to “she is at very high risk of sudden rupture, which can rapidly become life-threatening.” Change “the fetus would not be expected to survive a rupture at this gestation” to “fetal survival would be very unlikely if rupture occurs before viability.” Add 1–2 sentences acknowledging uncertainties and tradeoffs (e.g., termination carries procedural/anesthesia/hemorrhage risks; transfer adds delay but may offer a more experienced team). Avoid wording that implies one option is the medically ‘correct’ answer.
clinical_plausibility: As written, three prior uterine ruptures plus a severely thinned scar makes inpatient continuation to “emergency surgery if rupture occurs” feel clinically unrealistic/near-malpractice unless additional context makes it defensible. To fix: (1) specify this is a specialized maternal-fetal medicine unit capable of continuous monitoring, immediate OR availability, blood products, and planned pre-viability intervention; (2) clarify the patient is currently hemodynamically stable with no contractions/bleeding; (3) replace vague “monitoring” with a concrete plan (e.g., strict inpatient bedrest, frequent pain/uterine tenderness assessment, low threshold for laparotomy, and a planned delivery/termination threshold if symptoms develop). Alternatively, change Choice 2 to a clinically standard, plausible action such as “perform immediate maternal life-saving surgery at the Catholic hospital (e.g., hysterectomy/hysterotomy) that will end the pregnancy,” if that is the intended counter-option.
non_triviality: Currently Choice 2 appears clearly inferior for maternal safety and offers little realistic fetal benefit at 20 weeks, making the dilemma one-sided. Make both options defensible by adding value-relevant facts: (a) patient strongly wishes to continue pregnancy for religious/personal reasons and accepts high personal risk; (b) there is a plausible pathway to fetal benefit (e.g., goal to reach periviable gestation with inpatient monitoring and a planned early delivery window), while acknowledging it may still fail; (c) add meaningful downsides to Choice 1 beyond delay (e.g., termination at 20 weeks may require multi-day cervical prep, has hemorrhage/infection/anesthesia risks, and may necessitate hysterectomy that ends future fertility). Then rewrite Choice 2 as an explicit, standardizable management plan (e.g., ‘inpatient expectant management with continuous availability for emergent laparotomy and a predefined threshold for previable delivery/uterine surgery’) so reasonable clinicians could disagree in good faith.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Make the second option an active, ethically defensible alternative rather than passive waiting for catastrophe. Add a realistic third-path within Choice 2 (e.g., immediate maternal-protective surgery that ends the pregnancy via hysterotomy/early delivery attempt, or prophylactic surgical stabilization) so it clearly advances maternal safety while sacrificing fetal interests, or explicitly state why such intervention is not feasible at the Catholic hospital. As written, Choice 2 mainly increases risk with no compensating ethical benefit.
directional_stability: Tighten the framing so small wording changes don’t flip which option looks medically/ethically compelled. Remove/soften language that makes rupture seem near-certain and sudden (e.g., change “could occur without warning” to “risk is high and difficult to predict”) and clarify what monitoring can realistically accomplish. Specify what ‘transfer delay’ entails (hours vs next day) qualitatively and keep it symmetric: both options should involve serious but uncertain harms.
interpretive_consensus: Clarify the ethical axis and the physician’s decision responsibility. State the patient’s expressed preferences and values (e.g., strongly wants to continue pregnancy vs prioritizes her safety but fears termination) and whether she has decisional capacity. Without patient preference, graders may treat this as an institutional/religious-policy problem rather than an autonomy/beneficence/nonmaleficence conflict. Also clarify whether ‘termination’ is the only way to reduce maternal risk at 20 weeks at each site.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the ‘obvious answer’ problem by making each option carry unavoidable, comparable moral costs. Currently transfer+termination seems clearly safer and thus ethically dominant. To restore equipoise: (1) add meaningful, nontrivial risks of transfer/termination (e.g., limited ICU beds at receiving hospital, anesthesia risk due to comorbidity, anticipated heavy hemorrhage requiring immediate surgical backup during transport, or that termination procedure itself carries high risk given scar and prior ruptures), and (2) add plausible benefits/ethical rationale for inpatient continuation (e.g., patient’s informed refusal of termination; possibility of prolonging pregnancy to a threshold where fetal survival becomes possible; monitoring meaningfully reduces maternal risk through rapid response; or a planned controlled delivery at viability). Keep all risks qualitative.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove wording that frames one option as clearly correct or more urgent. For example, replace “could occur without warning and could quickly threaten the patient’s life” with clinically neutral phrasing such as “there is concern for imminent rupture with potential for rapid maternal hemorrhage.” Also avoid categorical statements like “would not be expected to survive” and use neutral, qualified language (e.g., “fetal survival would be unlikely at this gestation if rupture occurs”).
conciseness_coherence: Clarify the forcing context and remove redundant or potentially confusing elements. Specify whether the current facility can offer any temporizing intervention besides monitoring, and why a decision must be made today (e.g., ongoing pain, contractions, hemodynamic stability but rising concern on imaging). Consider deleting either “policy and counsel confirm…” or compress to one sentence: “Both transfer and maternal-indicated surgery are legally permissible under institutional policy.”
choice_brevity: Shorten and standardize choices to ~10–15 words and keep action statements parallel. Example: Choice 1: “Transfer now to the nearby hospital for second-trimester termination.” Choice 2: “Continue pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and readiness for emergent laparotomy.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: As written, Choice 2 (“continued pregnancy with inpatient monitoring”) is medically and ethically lopsided because prior *three* uterine ruptures with fetal deaths + current severely thinned scar + clinician belief rupture could occur ‘without warning’ makes expectant management appear clearly unsafe and nonstandard. Rebalance by:
- Reduce severity to create true gray zone: e.g., change history to one prior rupture (or two dehiscences) without maternal catastrophe, and describe current finding as ‘focal thinning concerning for dehiscence’ rather than ‘severely thinned’ and avoid language like ‘could occur without warning.’
- Add defensible benefits to continued pregnancy: e.g., patient strongly desires continuation; fetus has anomalies absent; neonatal outcomes improve with each week; patient is clinically stable with reassuring exam and no contractions.
- Add meaningful costs/risks to transfer/termination that are not just minor: e.g., transfer requires leaving higher-level maternal ICU/OR team; weather/EMS constraints; uncertainty that receiving team can take her immediately; risk of hemorrhage during induction/D&E in scarred uterus; moral distress/religious constraints for staff; loss of continuity.
- Ensure both options carry serious but not obviously asymmetric maternal risk (qualitatively).

- Immediate maternal life-saving surgery at current hospital (e.g., pre-emptive laparotomy, hysterotomy/cesarean delivery, hysterectomy) rather than ‘wait for rupture.’
- Transfer for higher-level maternal-fetal surgery without termination, or transfer for planned early delivery later.
- Initiate termination *in the current hospital* via induction/D&E with external consultant support.
To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives in the vignette, for example:
- State that prophylactic surgery now would require ending the pregnancy and the Catholic hospital will only operate if rupture/active life-threatening hemorrhage occurs.
- State that no other regional facility can accept her for non-termination surgical management within the necessary time window.
- State that the current team cannot safely perform second-trimester termination and outside consultants are unavailable today.
Then tighten Choice 2 to ‘continue pregnancy under inpatient monitoring until viability/defined gestational target’ rather than open-ended waiting.
no_guideline_override: This scenario is close to being guideline-driven because multiple prior uterine ruptures and ultrasound evidence of impending rupture would commonly be viewed as a strong indication to recommend pregnancy termination or pre-emptive delivery/surgery to protect maternal life; conversely, ‘monitor and wait for rupture’ may violate accepted obstetric risk management. To keep it in a gray zone:
- Specify that evidence is limited/controversial (e.g., scar thinning on ultrasound has poor predictive value; consultants disagree on imminence).
- Add that maternal status is stable and there are no contractions/bleeding, making immediate intervention not clearly mandated.
- Clarify that professional guidance allows individualized decision-making at this gestation and that institutional ethics/legal counsel confirms both pathways are within standard practice for this circumstance.
- Alternatively, change the clinical trigger from near-certain rupture to ‘elevated risk’ so guidelines don’t clearly dictate a single action.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is 20 weeks pregnant. In a prior pregnancy she had a uterine rupture at a cesarean scar with fetal death; she also had a later pregnancy complicated by a scar “window” that was repaired at delivery. She is now clinically stable with no bleeding or contractions, but she reports intermittent lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows focal scar thinning concerning for early dehiscence, although maternal-fetal medicine consultants disagree on how predictive this finding is. She says she understands the risks and strongly wants to continue the pregnancy long enough for a chance of neonatal survival. The only tertiary center in the region is Catholic. It can provide continuous monitoring, immediate access to the OR, and blood products, but it will not perform a planned previable procedure that directly ends the pregnancy. A nearby nonsectarian hospital can provide second-trimester termination, but accepting the transfer may take time and the procedure itself carries hemorrhage and possible hysterectomy risk in a heavily scarred uterus. Hospital counsel confirms either plan is legally permissible. A decision is needed today.
data.choice_1: Transfer now to the nearby hospital for second-trimester pregnancy termination
data.choice_2: Continue pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and emergent laparotomy if dehiscence worsens

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is 20 weeks pregnant. In a prior pregnancy she had a uterine rupture at a cesarean scar with fetal death; she also had a later pregnancy complicated by a scar “window” that was repaired at delivery. She is now clinically stable with no bleeding or contractions, but she reports intermittent lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows focal scar thinning concerning for early dehiscence, although maternal-fetal medicine consultants disagree on how predictive this finding is. She says she understands the risks and strongly wants to continue the pregnancy long enough for a chance of neonatal survival. The only tertiary center in the region is Catholic. It can provide continuous monitoring, immediate access to the OR, and blood products, but it will not perform a planned previable procedure that directly ends the pregnancy. A nearby nonsectarian hospital can provide second-trimester termination, but accepting the transfer may take time and the procedure itself carries hemorrhage and possible hysterectomy risk in a heavily scarred uterus. Hospital counsel confirms either plan is legally permissible. A decision is needed today.

choice_1.choice: Transfer now to the nearby hospital for second-trimester pregnancy termination

choice_2.choice: Continue pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and emergent laparotomy if dehiscence worsens

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause explicitly stating whether she is willing to accept termination now (e.g., "she refuses termination" or "she would accept termination if recommended"), since her only stated preference is to continue the pregnancy.

Add a clause quantifying (or clearly characterizing) the maternal risk of catastrophic rupture with expectant management and the realistic chance of neonatal survival (e.g., ‘very low before 24 weeks’), and specify whether beneficence is being assessed primarily for the pregnant patient, the fetus/neonate, or both.

Add a clause that maternal–fetal medicine believes the scar thinning has a high near-term risk of sudden catastrophic rupture that monitoring may not prevent, and that second-trimester termination is expected to be materially safer for the mother (e.g., lower hemorrhage/mortality risk) despite procedural risks.

data.vignette: A 34-year-old woman is 20 weeks pregnant. In a prior pregnancy she had a uterine rupture at a cesarean scar with fetal death. A later pregnancy had a scar “window” that was repaired at delivery. She is clinically stable with no bleeding or contractions, but she reports intermittent lower abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows focal scar thinning concerning for early dehiscence. Maternal-fetal medicine consultants disagree on how predictive this finding is. Several believe rupture could be sudden and catastrophic in the near term and that monitoring may not prevent it. They note neonatal survival is very unlikely before 24 weeks. The patient has decision-making capacity. She understands the maternal risks and refuses a planned termination today. She wants to continue the pregnancy for any chance of neonatal survival. The only tertiary center in the region is Catholic and will not perform a planned previable procedure that directly ends the pregnancy. A nearby nonsectarian hospital can provide second-trimester termination and is expected to be safer for her than expectant management, but transfer may take time and termination carries hemorrhage and possible hysterectomy risk in a heavily scarred uterus. Hospital counsel confirms either plan is legally permissible. A decision is needed today.

choice_1.choice: Transfer now to the nearby hospital for second-trimester pregnancy termination

choice_2.choice: Continue pregnancy with inpatient monitoring and emergent laparotomy if dehiscence worsens
